narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the COVID pandemic and changes in bioethics.

An in-depth understanding of the fascinating field of bioethics -- far deeper and more free (in discussion and topic area) than the lecture. With the ongoing COVID crisis, much of the class was focused on Prof. Latham's work in COVID which was actually super interesting inside baseball to hear.
Learned about bioethics issues in America: abortion, vaccination, racial disparities in health care, pandemics, and other pressing issues facing the nation.

I developed in depth knowledge on several public health and bioethic policies. I learned a lot about health disparities in regard to Covid and how public health measures were carried out in response to the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths - I loved the books we read and really enjoyed the topics discussed.
Weaknesses - Professor Latham basically lectures the whole time. There is not much time for the students to discuss, but you know that going in if you read the reviews. It would be helpful to do a 3/4 and 1/4 split of lecture to discussion so people can be more engaged. It is easy to get distracted on a laptop.

I imagine this course could've been so much better if we were in person, but I have no complaints otherwise. Zoom seminars are generally very difficult and this was more of a leminar, but a very interesting one!

This course was fabulous. Professor Latham is so knowledgeable about anything you could imagine in the field. Hearing his and scholarly perspectives on issues reframed them in ways other courses have not.
Stephen Latham is a huge strength for this course. He is incredibly knowledgeable and passionate. Although, I would have wished that this course was more discussion based.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We didn't do anything special on Zoom, but I would recommend breakout rooms for this class or a virtual debate.
COVID seminars generally are super hard for me to engage in, and I'm not sure if a change in methods or format can help that.

Live seminars are inevitably tough for those with variable schedules due to COVID-related difficulties, but that is no one's fault. The course succeeded in providing a forum where pressing questions about COVID could be addressed during the seminar.
The seminar style worked well over Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this if you want a lecture. We didn't discuss much. Also, your entire grade is the final paper which you submit during reading period so as I write the review, I have no idea how the grading is. I think Professor Latham said he is a kind grader, but it is a stressful situation to have your entire grade be one paper. I would recommend only taking this if you are confident in your paper.

Yes, this course is incredibly difficult to get into and if you do get in, its worth taking to get to know Professor Latham better alone. He is incredibly supportive to his students and has a set of expertise and worldview that I could listen to for days.
MUST TAKE! So interesting, important, meaningful, enjoyable, and everything you could ever ask of in a course.
Yes definitely!
Yes, definitely. I loved Professor Latham and the syllabus was well designed.
